[[Hermeneutics]] | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = }} '''Vanessa Lemm''' is inaugural Vice-President and Executive Dean of the College of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences, [[Flinders University]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/people/vanessa.lemm|title=Vanessa Lemm|website=www.flinders.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-06-27}} She is also Chief Editor of the journal, ''Nietzsche Studien'' and known for her research on the ideas of [[Friedrich Nietzsche]] and [[Michel Foucault]].[http://hum.leiden.edu/philosophy/news-agenda/mini-seminar-biopolitics.html Mini-course on Biopolitics][https://global.oup.com/academic/product/nietzsche-and-the-becoming-of-life-9780823262861?cc=us&lang=en& Nietzsche and the Becoming of Life][http://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/journal_of_nietzsche_studies/v034/34.1lemm.html Is Nietzsche a Perfectionist?][http://www.pdcnet.org/collection/show?id=newnietzsche_2011_0008_41337_0129_0142&file_type=pdf On Nietzsche’s Animal Philosophy][http://www.nietzschecircle.com/AGONIST/2010_03/PDFs/AgonistMAR2010TuncelReview.pdf Review of Nietzsche’s Animal Philosophy][http://www.abc.net.au/radionational/programs/lifematters/what-do-we-owe-each-other3a-community-in-the-21st-century/4152660 What do we owe each other: community in the 21st century][http://www.publimetro.cl/nota/cronica/columna-de-libros-de-ensayos-y-otras-adicciones/xIQmdl!Psk8NR0qq83fw/ Columna de libros: De ensayos y otras adicciones] ==Career== Before moving to Australia, Lemm was Director of the Institute of Humanities at the [[Diego Portales University]] in Santiago de Chile and DAAD Visiting Professor at the Institute for Philosophy at the [[University of Potsdam]], Germany. At the [[University of New South Wales]] she was professor of [[philosophy]] and head of the School of Humanities and Languages for more than four years. During this time she was elected Fellow of the [[Royal Society of New South Wales]] (FRSN).{{Cite web|url=https://www.royalsoc.org.au/about-us/fellows|title=Fellows - The Royal Society of NSW|website=www.royalsoc.org.au|access-date=2018-06-27}} Lemm took up her appointment as Vice-President and Executive Dean of the new College of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences at Flinders University on 22 January 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.flinders.edu.au/fit/2017/09/11/new-leader-appointed-to-college-of-humanities-arts-and-social-sciences/|title=New chapter for College of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences - Flinders In Touch|date=2017-09-11|work=Flinders In Touch|access-date=2018-06-27|language=en-US}} ==Bibliography== * Lemm V; Vatter M, (eds.), 2014, ''The Government of Life: Foucault, Biopolitics and Neoliberalism'', Fordham University Press, New York * Lemm V, 2013, ''Nietzsche y el pensamiento político contemporáneo'', Fondo de cultura económica, Santiago de Chile * Lemm V, 2012, ''Nietzsches Philosophie des Tieres'', Diaphanes Verlag, Berlin/Zürich * Lemm V, (ed.), 2010, ''Michel Foucault: neoliberalismo y biopolítica'', Ediciones Universidad Diego Portales, Santiago de Chile * Lemm V; Ormeño J, (eds.), 2010, ''Hegel, pensador de la actualidad'', Ediciones Universidad Diego Portales, Santiago de Chile * Lemm V, 2009, ''Nietzsche's Animal Philosophy: Culture, Politics and the Animality of the Human Being'', Fordham University Press, New York ==See also== *[[Biopolitics]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YcmiOK9dGBA Professor Vanessa Lemm: What do we owe one another? He is the [[editor-in-chief]] of [[Zygon (journal)|''Zygon, Journal of Religion & Science'']].{{cite web|url=http://www.zygonjournal.org/editorial_9_09.html |title=Zygon: Journal of Religion and Science |publisher=Zygonjournal.org |date= |accessdate=2012-07-06}} As of 1 November 2014 he is a humanities professor of philosophy at [[Tilburg University]] in the Netherlands. ==Biography== Drees was born in the Hague on April 20, 1954, as the third child of five and the only son of [[Willem Drees jr]] (1922–1998) and Anna Erica Drees-Gescher (1922–1988). His paternal grandfather [[Willem Drees]] was the prime minister of the Netherlands from 1948 until 1958.{{cite web|title=Dr. W. (Willem) Drees|url=https://www.parlement.com/id/vg09ll01jztw/w_willem_drees|website=www.parlement.com|language=nl}} His father was also a Netherlands politician being the party leader of the [[Democratic Socialists '70]] from 1971 to 1977.{{cite web|title=Dr. W. (Wim) Drees jr|url=https://www.parlement.com/id/vg09llecbrzz/w_wim_drees|website=www.parlement.com|language=nl}} Drees is a past-president of the [[European Society for the Study of Science and Theology]] (ESSSAT).{{cn|date=April 2018}} According to Tillburg University, Drees "was also dean of the Faculty of Theology and vice-dean of the Faculty of Humanities." As of 1 November 2014, he is a professor of philosophy within the Tilburg School of Humanities.{{cite press release|title=Persbericht Tilburg University 28 mei 2014|url=https://uvtapp.uvt.nl/tsb11/npc.npc.showpressreleasecm?v_id=6467821878823705|website=uvtapp.uvt.nl|language=Dutch}} Drees has been the editor and publisher of numerous books, journal articles, essays, book reviews and articles for the wider public. His books include ''Beyond the Big Bang: Quantum Cosmologies and God'' (1990), ''Religion, Science and Naturalism'' (1996), and ''Creation: From Nothing until Now'' (2002). ==Religious naturalism and science== ===Naturalism=== Drees addressed the analysis of cosmology limit questions with the interpretation of the explanatory success of science. His second Fulbright grant resulted in the book - ''Religion, Science and Naturalism'' (1996). [[John H. Brooke]], historian of science and religion, concluded a review of work of the Oxford theologian [[Keith Ward]] and Drees’s book: ''“Because he is as secure in his epistemology as in his knowledge of theoretical physics, Willem Drees should be read by all who take a scholarly interest in the discourses of ‘science and religion’. His arguments cannot be compressed into sound-bites, and that is their strength.”'' John H. Brooke - [[Times Literary Supplement]] , February 7, 1997 The analysis of [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalism]] as addressed in his ''Religious Naturalism and Science'' has remained a major component in Drees’s research.''The Oxford Handbook of Religion and Science'' (2006) He has also paid attention in his analysis of naturalism to the understanding of human nature, with two edited volumes on anthropology and non-reductive physicalism in Dutch and one in English (2000). William A. Rottschaefer argues that Drees’s naturalism is seriously flawed claiming that it is both methodologically and epistemologically naturalistic. Drees maintains while rejecting both of these that [[ontological naturalism]] offers the best account of the natural world. It also provides for a supernaturalistic understanding of religion and theology. Although naturalism is often considered to be antithetical to theology and genuine religion, Drees proposes a scientifically informed account of religion, which, he contends, is not only compatible with supernaturalism and theology but provides a better account of both.[http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/journal/118976751/abstract?CRETRY=1&SRETRY=0 ''How to Make Naturalism Safe for Supernaturalism: An Evaluation of Willem Drees's Supernaturalistic Naturalism''] by William A. Rottschaefer ===Religious Naturalism=== As the Vice President for Interdisciplinary Affairs of IRAS, Drees has participated in the formulative discussions of [[Religious Naturalism]] and helped organize a conference on Human Meaning in a Technological Culture (2001). When it comes to his position on this emerging worldview, Drees, says of himself:
Am I a religious naturalist? Others have used that label on me. I am not sure I like the label, as it seems to constrain, whereas I want to explore. I also have some sympathy for the naturalistic theism described above. But certainly, precisely in the attitude of exploring, I fit the naturalism referenced above. Or I at least, I hope do. Even if I am not sure whether I am a religious naturalist, I am most interested in understanding what religious naturalism might mean, may become, and will offer.{{cite book|last1=Clayton|first1=Philip|last2=Simpson|first2=Zachary|title=The Oxford Handbook of Religion and Science|date=2006|publisher=OUP Oxford|isbn=9780199279272|url=https://books.google.com/?id=eyrikGwJfCsC&pg=PA108&dq=Willem+b.+drees|language=en}}{{cite web|title=Past Conferences|url=http://www.iras.org/pastconferences.html|website=IRAS|language=en}}
[[Jerome A. Stone]] in his 2008 book ''Religious Naturalism Today: The Rebirth of a Forgotten Alternative'' cites Drees as one of the leaders of the Religious Naturalism movement along with other member of IRAS – [[Ursula Goodenough]], [[Karl Peters]], Connie Barlow, Michael Cavanaugh and Stone himself.{{cite book|last1=Stone|first1=Jerome Arthur|title=Religious Naturalism Today: The Rebirth of a Forgotten Alternative|date=2009|publisher=International Society for Science and Religion|isbn=9780791475379|language=English|oclc=756930510}}{{page needed|date=April 2018}} ==Works== {{Lacking ISBN|date=April 2018}} ===Books, edited volumes and inaugural addresses=== *''Naked Ape or Techno Sapiens?
